Brilliant video! Great selection of information, pacing, mood, everything. A couple of small points. Your graph shows CO2 exceeding the historic range in 1950, but it passed the 300 ppm threshold in 1910 (search "Global Mean CO2 Mixing Ratios (ppm): Observations"). Good to mention lamb as well as beef (at least for Australian viewers). And when you mention CCS you could add that we'll need it to bring atmospheric CO2 back to safe levels, because (important point) cutting emissions to zero is just the first step.
Thanks, great feedback! Probably won't update the video (waaay too time consuming), but I'll create some kind of addendum/corrections. Will definitely add these points there.

Amazing video. Probably one of the best videos I have seen regarding the challenges associated with the issue, and it really taught me a lot. Exactly what I was looking for =]

Do you think you could maybe do another one that focuses a little more specifically on the SCIENCE behind the actual impacts of the "nasty consequences" that are caused by climate change, and possibly which areas in the world are affected by specific problems the most and why?

So basically, expand in scientific terms a lot more of what goes on between 1:30 - 3:00 ? Maybe along the frame of something like this: https://bigpictureeducation.com/how-does-climate-change-affect-human-health but using more scientific terms and quick stats to back up and relate to what is being discussed? Maybe using key stats to round up the main facts, like 97% of all scientists supporting findings, actual temp of water and how much it's going up by, actual height of the rising sea level, and what different heights will mean and pointing out the most vulnerable places in the world and relate to what specific damage they could cause, etc.

Like, say explaining one by one the things like rising sea levels, drought, forest fire, flood, and like how more specifically they could lead to economic collapse and war, for instance. Like, if you were doing drought, could you explain through more scientific the things that cause drought (e.g. thermal expansion polar icecaps, maybe focus on which parts of the world are most vulnerable and how associated factors are exacerbated by climate change and can cause things like loss of agricultural land, etc?

It would also be really nice if you could tie in a decent amount about the relationship between atmosphere and seawater.

Phew, sorry if that list was a bit long winded, it's just that good content that's as easy to understand like this is so difficult to find! If you could explain the SCIENCE behind these things in more detail as well, then that would be incredible =] The format is just amazing though! Really helpful and very easy to understand =] Keep up the good work ^_-
Good to hear. Yeah, the goal of the video is to cover the gap between shallow media and long hard-to-digest science reports.

Sorry if my suggestions were a little long winded, it's just that content like yours on this issue seems extremely rare (and I have to wonder why ...) and I just find it frustrating that I find it difficult to find all the sources I would like to learn more about global warming summarized in one place, let alone in a format that's as easy to understand as this fantastic piece here. This is a truly amazing video! Keep up the good work!!

now this sounds like driving around with your car is really really really bad for the environment. (globaly not localy speaking) since i couldnt not find the actual statistics or numbers that you used because your sitation is literally a compilation of about 2500 papers on extremely divers topics and the ones i was looking for either didnt exist or would cost me about 150‚Ç¨ to purchase i had to look it up myself.
now the number that i found ( https://www.eea.europa.eu/data-and-maps/indicators/transport-emissions-of-greenhouse-gases/transport-emissions-of-greenhouse-gases-11 ) regarding the percentage of emissions caused by transport is almost DOUBLE the amount that you had (27% compaired to 14%) which shocked me since that would make it even worse. now what i actually had an issue with was that you casually state that most of these transport emissions are caused by cars, implying that passenger cars where actually the big deal in this equasion. and while you mentioned that you include trucks and busses etc. the actual numbers are really importand.
according to my source (link above) only 44% of roadtransport-emissions are caused by passenger cars. so we got 44% from the 3/4 (roadtransport) that you mentioned in your video. now i dont know if the 14% or the 27% is more acurate so i might just use the middle (=20.5%)
now we have 44% from 3/4 (actually 71%) from 20.5% as total emissions caused by passenger cars.

thats a total of ~6.4% total emissions caused by passenger cars.
(disclaimer: my understanding of the article could be completely wrong and there is a good chance of my math being off a good bit)
otherwise i really liked your video!

Beef is the worst type of meat, but don't forget dairy. The single most impactful change you can make to fight climate change is to switch to a plant based diet. Pigs and chicken also tend to be fed from monoculture soy and corn. Why are they burning the Amazon? To grow more soy to feed animals to feed humans. Grazing land too, but not exclusively. The expert panel formed by the UN declared that we need to switch to a plant based diet to avoid irreversable climate change.

P.S. I don't miss cheese now that i have discovered nutritional yeast. Just as good as Parmesan cheese. To get a snack that tastes like cheese, I eat a Cheetos alternative called Hippeas. There are so many plant milks to choose from that you are bound to like one of them. You can even choose the level of sweetness.

Henrik, your explainers are damned beautiful. But I have some caveats here:

A minor one: methane from permafrost melt only lasts in the atmosphere for 12 years, so won't be much of a climate force over time.

A major one: solar and wind aren't reliable replacements because we can't store the energy for use when it's dark and cloudy or calm, respectively. Storage technologies are an enormous bugbear and while I'm fond of some of the solution ideas, especially flywheel banks and EnergyNest's thermal storage, these things are far from ready to deploy en masse. Battery storage isn't catching up fast at anywhere near the rate we need. I suggest you look harder at this.

And a huge solution element you miss is the decentralisation of population through 3D printing and augmented reality. We can already 3D print houses, clothes, tools and food. With augmented reality, we will no longer need to centralise housing to run our organizations or fuel mass transport from hub to hub. And with 3D printed food - from vats of stem cells - we will no longer need to use most of our land for agriculture. So we'll rapidly spread out into villages across the former farmlands and present day cities will become museums over the next two generations.

Provided climate change disruptions don't wreck us all first.
Good points, and good links. Thanks!

Great video. Here's another source on pumped hydro: the late David MacKay (actually his book is a great- & necessary- source for everything on energy) https://www.withouthotair.com/sewthacontents.shtml https://www.withouthotair.com/c26/page_192.shtml Various forms of optimism and craziness (of all schemes though, pumped hydro is off-the-shelf, 20th century tech). https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/Norway-Could-Provide-20000-MW-of-Energy-Storage-to-Europe scottishscientist.wordpress.com/2015/04/15/worlds-biggest-ever-pumped-storage-hydro-scheme-for-scotland/ MacKay ended up thinking nuclear would be necessary for the UK, though some (sunnier and less population dense) parts of the world have much better options for a high proportion of renewables. https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/03/idea-of-renewables-powering-uk-is-an-appalling-delusion-david-mackay Other notes: 1 - this project should be much better known: globalcalculator.org 2 - your pie chart of emissions would be enhanced by having a per capita pie chart for wealthy, YouTube browsing Westerners (and their children). On that pie chart, air travel may be as much as 50% (or more). http://www.yesmagazine.org/issues/life-after-oil/how-far-can-we-get-without-flying-20160211 https://theconversation.com/life-in-a-post-flying-australia-and-why-it-might-actually-be-ok-70388
Hey you seem very knowledgeable about this subject. Would love to have you in our community. http://climate.crisp.se

Hi Henrik, thanks for your thoughtful replies. Pumped hydro storage doesn't presently scale very well above the needs of a small town. There's a nice treatment of it at http://physics.ucsd.edu/do-the-math/2011/11/pump-up-the-storage/ . Nevertheless, http://www.gravitypower.net/ looks like a good way to deal with that. Another solution that looks promising is http://www.energy-nest.com/home/ . Both these technologies are in their infancy, but there are commercial pilots for both and in principal I can see no obstacles to scaling. 3D printed food from stem cells is further from commercial reality. http://www.nbcnews.com/mach/innovation/lab-grown-meat-may-save-lot-more-farm-animals-lives-n743091 is a recent summary of progress. I think it's fair to regard full commercial scale for it as a decade away. The same probably goes for full scale commercial 3D-printed buildings. Full augmented reality is closer. 5G wireless networks already pack sufficient bandwidth for it - tens of gigbits per second - and the first practical AR goggles - MS Hololens - are already on the market. Within 5 years AR will be commonplace in a sunglasses form factor and in a decade mobile phones will look as quaint to the kids as wall-tethered phones do today. So ... all these technologies will be commercial within a decade, and together will have social implications just as profound as the Internet's impact over the past decade. They won't put the climate genie back in its bottle, but they're globally applicable so will rapidly cut carbon-polluting activities to pre-industrial levels. That leaves us with a "simpler" problem to solve. Not how do we stop putting carbon in the air - that's coming so long as we can just stay civilised. The "simpler" problem is, how do we deal with the irreversible positive feedback loops we've put into motion? When the last of the arctic sea ice melts - possibly as soon as this year - we're going to see climate processes kick in that haven't operated for at least 125,000 years. No one has the foggiest idea what will happen then. The one thing we know for certain is it will happen faster than any of our models. Greenland, for example, is melting 900% faster than any of the models due to dark-coloured algal blooms forming on the surface of its ice. They were only discovered last year, and none of the models account for them. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DKfP63NH4DM 125,000 years ago, there was a sudden and enormous influx of fresh water into the oceans around Bermuda. We know this because of patterns of growth in fossilised shellfish. And he fresh water conditions lasted for several centuries. http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2016PA003014/abstract If Greenland's ice isn't stable under the conditions that are about to occur, we may experience a sudden rise in ocean levels of about 7 meters. That would inundate almost all large cities around the planet all at once. And, if that happened, staying civilised might not be a simple thing to do at all.
Another inspiring example "El Hierro, the Spanish island vying for 100% clean energy" https://phys.org/news/2016-04-el-hierro-spanish-island-vying.html

Like for example this: "Germany converting a huge coal mine into giant renewable battery" http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/germany-coal-mine-convert-renewable-battery-hydroelectric-prosper-haniel-north-rhine-westphalia-a7648841.html

The batteries are useful for peak shaving and short term storage, but don't really scale (at least not yet). For larger volumes, things like Hydro storage look promising: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pumped-storage_hydroelectricity

Tesla's Powerwall sure looks promising though. I'm sure some commercial breakthrough is going to happen soon enough in the battery development! 3D printing and augmented reality seems even further away in time imo.

Thanks for the feedback. Good points. As for energy storage, yes, it isn't solved yet. But things are moving fast, a lot of really exciting innovation happening with energy storage, both long term and short term. Solar/Wind doesn't completely replace fossil fuels yet, but it can certainly reduce it. But in the long term, burning fossil fuels for energy is simply not an option. 3D printed food sounds very exciting, haven't looked into that in detail. I really doubt we could convince everyone one to be came vegetarian (struggle with that myself), so I really hope someone comes up with a way to grow/print a viable meat-analog.
